title: The most groundbreaking scientist you've never heard of - Addison Anderson

options.label: B

options.label: C

What was Nicolas Steno's maxim that described the pursuit of truth and understanding?

options.label: A
options.text: "Beautiful is what we see, more beautiful is what we know, most beautiful, by far, is what we don't"

options.label: B
options.text: "The truth is what we observe, the rest is speculation"

options.label: C
options.text: "The pursuit of knowledge is a never-ending journey"

options.label: D
options.text: "The unknown is what drives human curiosity"

title: The physics of human sperm vs. the physics of the sperm whale

multiple-choice.question: What did physicist Edward Purcell calculate in 1977 regarding bacteria?

options.label: A
options.text: That bacteria can swim at speeds of up to 100 miles per hour.

options.label: B
options.text: That bacteria can travel several inches in a single second.

options.label: C
options.text: That bacteria will stop in about a millionth of a second if pushed and then let go.

options.label: D
options.text: That bacteria are capable of jumping long distances.

multiple-choice.question: Why is it difficult for microscopic creatures to swim through water?

options.label: A
options.text: Because water molecules are too small to interact with the creatures.

options.label: B
options.text: Because water molecules are too large and dense, making it hard for creatures to push past them.

options.label: C
options.text: Because water molecules outnumber the creatures, making it difficult for them to move through the water.

options.label: D
options.text: Because water molecules are too sticky, causing the creatures to get stuck.

multiple-choice.question: What is the Reynolds number, and what does it depend on?

options.label: A
options.text: The Reynolds number is a measure of a fluid's viscosity and depends on the fluid's temperature and pressure.

options.label: B
options.text: The Reynolds number is a measure of a swimmer's speed and depends on the swimmer's size and the fluid's density.

options.label: C
options.text: The Reynolds number is a measure of a fluid's behavior and depends on the size of the swimmer, its speed, the density of the fluid, and the fluid's viscosity.

options.label: D
options.text: The Reynolds number is a measure of a swimmer's efficiency and depends on the swimmer's shape and the fluid's flow rate.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between the world of a sperm whale and the world of a sperm?

options.label: A
options.text: The sperm whale lives in a world with much stronger currents than the sperm.

options.label: B
options.text: The sperm whale lives in a world with much denser water than the sperm.

options.label: C
options.text: The sperm whale lives in a world with a high Reynolds number, while the sperm lives in a world with a low Reynolds number.

options.label: D
options.text: The sperm whale lives in a world with much warmer water than the sperm.

multiple-choice.question: How do some microbes manage to move through the water despite the challenges of their size?

options.label: A
options.text: They use powerful muscles to push through the water.

options.label: B
options.text: They deform the shape of their paddles to create more drag on the power stroke.

options.label: C
options.text: They use chemical engineering to thin out the surrounding water.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the helical tail of bacteria and sperm?

options.label: A
options.text: To increase their speed through the water.

options.label: C
options.text: To push themselves forward in a world where water feels as thick as cork.

multiple-choice.question: How do some bacteria use grappling hooks to move through the water?

options.label: A
options.text: They use the grappling hooks to pull themselves along.

options.label: B
options.text: They use the grappling hooks to push themselves forward.

options.label: C
options.text: They use the grappling hooks to change direction quickly.

options.label: D
options.text: They use the grappling hooks to attach themselves to other organisms.

options.label: C
options.text: Its ability to release a chemical that thins out the surrounding mucus.

multiple-choice.question: What would be the consequence if bacteria and sperm were unable to adapt to their environments?

options.label: A
options.text: They would be able to swim faster and more efficiently.

options.label: B
options.text: They would be able to find food more easily.

options.label: C
options.text: They would never find their hosts or make it to their eggs, resulting in the inability to reproduce.

options.label: D
options.text: They would be able to defend against predators more effectively.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea of the transcript regarding the movement of microscopic creatures?

options.label: A
options.text: That they are able to move quickly and efficiently through the water.

options.label: B
options.text: That they are unable to move through the water due to their size.

options.label: C
options.text: That they have evolved unique adaptations to overcome the challenges of their size and environment.

options.label: D
options.text: That they are able to swim long distances without getting tired.

title: Can we domesticate germs? - Paul Ewald

multiple-choice.question: What type of disease organisms did the speaker focus on in the talk?

options.label: A
options.text: The idea that disease organisms have to get from one host to another and often rely on the well-being of the host to move to another host.

options.label: B
options.text: The idea that disease organisms are more likely to cause damage if they are transmitted through water.

options.label: C
options.text: The idea that disease organisms are more likely to cause damage if they are transmitted through person-to-person contact.

options.label: D
options.text: The idea that disease organisms are more likely to cause damage if they are transmitted through food.

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: The organism will evolve to be more harmful.

options.label: C
options.text: The organism will not evolve at all.

options.label: B
options.text: Take a single strain of the organism and release it in a country with a high level of waterborne transmission.

options.label: C
options.text: Take a single strain of the organism and release it in a country with a low level of waterborne transmission.

options.label: D

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: Use a combination of antibiotics and other treatments.

options.label: B
options.text: That waterborne transmission is a contributing factor to the harmfulness of diarrheal disease organisms.

options.label: C
options.text: That waterborne transmission has no effect on the harmfulness of diarrheal disease organisms.

options.label: D
options.text: That waterborne transmission is the only factor that determines the harmfulness of diarrheal disease organisms.

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: That mosquito-proof houses are the only way to control malaria.

multiple-choice.question: What is the expected outcome if a disease organism is transmitted through a vector such as a mosquito?

options.label: A
options.text: The organism will evolve to be more mild.

options.label: B
options.text: The organism will evolve to be more harmful.

options.label: C
options.text: The organism will not evolve at all.

options.label: A
options.text: That disease organisms are more likely to cause damage if they are transmitted through water.

options.label: B

title: Bird migration, a perilous journey - Alyssa Klavans

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary reason why song birds migrate to Central and South America during the winter?

options.label: B
options.text: To store fat for the winter

options.label: D
options.text: To prepare for the physical stress of migration
